title: Homograph Attack - University Portal
description: A phishing site using an internationalized domain name (IDN homograph attack) to create a visually identical URL to the university portal.
context: You received an email from what appears to be your university's registrar office, informing you that your course registration for next semester is about to be canceled due to an unpaid balance. The email asks you to log in to verify your student account. You click the link and arrive at this page. The URL in the address bar appears to show your university's domain.

content.page_html:
MyUniversity

Student Portal

Action Required: Your course registration will be canceled in 48 hours due to an outstanding balance of $1,247.00. Please log in to verify and resolve.






Forgot Password? | IT Help Desk

© 2025 MyUniversity. All rights reserved. | Privacy Policy | Terms of Use

red_flags.label: IDN homograph attack — URL contains look-alike Unicode characters
red_flags.detail: The 'i' in 'university' has been replaced with the Cyrillic character 'і' (U+0456). These look identical in most fonts but resolve to completely different domains. This is called an IDN homograph attack.

red_flags.label: Requests date of birth on login page
red_flags.detail: A legitimate university login page requires only your student ID and password. Asking for date of birth is a data harvesting technique.

red_flags.label: Threat of course cancellation creates high-stakes urgency
red_flags.detail: For a student, losing course registration is a serious threat. This emotional manipulation overrides careful analysis of the page.

red_flags.label: Specific dollar amount adds false legitimacy
red_flags.detail: The precise $1,247.00 amount makes the claim feel real. But specificity in a phishing page is just a design choice — attackers know specific numbers are more convincing.

red_flags.label: Login was initiated from an email link, not bookmarks
red_flags.detail: You arrived at this page by clicking an email link rather than navigating to the portal yourself. Critical logins should always be done via bookmarks or typed URLs.

actions.label: Enter your student ID, password, and date of birth
actions.feedback: The attacker now has your university credentials AND personal information (DOB). They can access your student records, financial aid, and potentially commit identity fraud.

actions.label: Enter just your student ID to check the balance first
actions.feedback: Even partial information is valuable to attackers. Your student ID alone can be used for social engineering in future attacks against you or the university.

actions.label: Close this tab and navigate to the university portal via your bookmarks
actions.feedback: Excellent security practice! By navigating directly via bookmarks or typing the URL, you bypass any homograph or lookalike domain tricks entirely.

actions.label: Inspect the SSL certificate to verify the actual domain
actions.feedback: Advanced and effective! Checking the SSL certificate reveals the actual punycode domain (xn--myuniversty-...) which exposes the homograph attack. This is a technique security professionals use.

learning_objectives: Understand IDN homograph attacks — visually identical characters from different scripts
Always navigate to important portals via bookmarks or typed URLs, never email links
SSL certificates can reveal the true domain behind homograph attacks
Login pages should never ask for more than username and password
Modern browsers show punycode for mixed-script domains — learn to check the URL bar
High-stakes threats (registration cancellation) are used to override careful judgment
